section.title: Break
section.para: While there tend to be few, if any, net to net differences in the use of the word Break, there are operator to operator differences. It is significant because MARS usage of the word is quite different than amateur radio use.

In many cases, amateurs can benefit from observing the generally more disciplined MARS practice. However, in this case, the use of the word Break is well-established in amateur radio and at odds with MARS use, so stations should be careful to avoid the MARS practice in this instance.
Further complicating the issue is the fact that Break is used entirely differently in the context of a formal message than it's use outside a message.

section.title: Break within a message
section.para: When used within the context of a formal message, Break has almost the same meaning as the CW "double-dash" character; a break between sections of a message. The Break proword is used between the address and the body of a message, and between the body and the signature.

On phone, Break has the added implication that the sender intends to release the microphone so that the receiving station may ask for fills, although this step is often omitted before the signature. On CW, this is not necessary since most stations can receive while transmitting.

section.title: Break outside a message
section.para: In amateur practice, a Break outside the context of a formal message means "I need to interrupt this conversation for something important". Break Break means "I need to interrupt this conversation because of an emergency". This is rather dramatically different than MARS practice, which is to use Break much the same as inside a message, so stations should be careful to avoid MARS practice and caution others as well.
